The allegations of complicit corruption amongst some New South Wales government officials are, if anything, even more concerning. The Sydney Daily Telegraph alleges that there have been some secret deals between the New South Wales Nationals and large irrigators, one of whom is the subject of the Four Corners investigation. We are not talking about small amounts of water here, and some of the properties in question have multiple mega dams which are measured in multiples of the Sydney Harbour rather than in mere multiples of swimming pools. The federal government has spent billions of dollars of taxpayers' money on water buybacks, and now we have no idea what they have to show for it. The communities in my own electorate right at the end of the Murray, the most vulnerable part of the Murray, now feel very angry and betrayed, and rightfully so. Let me tell you something about the southern end of the basin, where we have still have not recovered fully from the effects of the last drought.

Farmers on the river, and particularly in the Lower Lakes, have told me how much their agricultural techniques have changed in the last few decades to adapt to less water, and how, despite all of the new efficiencies, it won't be enough if the river does not fully recover before the next drought hits. Only a few months ago a group of business leaders sought a meeting with me because they feared northern irrigators would start clawing back water. Little did we know that the clawbacks may have already occurred, and under the table. Indeed, family farms in country towns the entire length of the River Murray and its tributaries have the right to ask what is happening to our water, and to get a clear and honest response. Instead, we have seen what can only be described as a farcical response from the Leader of the Nationals, whose party has such a bedfellow relationship with its mega irrigators that it defines the very meaning of conflict of interest. I believe, in light of the allegations, it is only proper that Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce step aside from the water ministry, and that the portfolio should not be held by a National Party member until all of the allegations can be resolved. To do anything less will destroy what little faith downstream communities have left in the regulatory framework that is supposed to uphold our national Basin Plan. Fishers at the end of the river system have accused the Deputy Prime Minister of placing his foot on the Coorong's neck. They are petitioning the Prime Minister to remove the Deputy Prime Minister from the water ministry and they are demanding a full independent inquiry into the Four Corners allegations and no cuts to environmental flows, and I agree with them. There are incidents—
Mr Pasin: Maybe we should kill the seals!

Ms SHARKIE: Why don't you stand up and talk about the River Murray, Member for Barker? You've been deafening in your absolute silence on this. There are indications that the claims aired on Four Corners are but the tip of the iceberg. I believe that we can expect similar allegations to come to light across the basin.

The Nick Xenophon Team welcomes the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry, and my colleague Senator Xenophon has written to the inquiry requesting that they urgently investigate the allegations that inside information was given to lobbyists by the New South Wales government department, and why water enforcement investigations appear only to have been curtailed. The New South Wales ICAC is a welcome step, but it is a small step in comparison to the sheer scale of the allegations.

It all leads to one conclusion: the only way to resolve such shocking allegations of grand scale theft and major corruption is to launch a full judicial inquiry with the powers of a royal commission. Anything short of a full judicial inquiry is just an attempt to sweep these allegations under the rug, or perhaps to hope that they wash away. I put to the federal government, and, in particular, to the National Party: if you have nothing to hide, then you have nothing to fear from a judicial review. Yet all I hear, and all South Australia hears, and all the communities up and down the river hear is silence—deafening silence—particularly, disappointingly, from the South Australian federal members of the Liberal Party. They should stand up for their state and they should also call for a judicial review. We need to put our state above any party politics. I might say that the state Liberal Party is supporting this, and I commend them for that.

Before I conclude, I would like to say a few words on the Murray-Darling Basin Plan. As a result of the Four Corners investigation, some have sought to criticise the plan and the planners rather than the alleged plotters. Let me be clear: the Murray-Darling Basin Plan is not perfect. No plan ever is perfect. But it is a good plan, and it is our plan. It is a shared plan born of compromise—the hallmark of a well-functioning democracy. It is our national plan, and we must stick to our national plan. The alternative is that our great River Murray-Darling system, which is already on a trajectory for a full-scale collapse, still has a possibility of running dry, and there will be no water for anyone. We cannot allow this to happen to our great nation.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mrs Wicks ): There being no further grievances, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
QUESTIONS IN WRITING

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment: Dentsu Mitchell Media Australia (Question No. 62)

p.span: Department of Employment: Dentsu Mitchell Media Australia
(Question No. 62)
Mr Keogh asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, in writing, on 7 November 2016:

In respect of the $45,454.55 contract to Dentsu Mitchell Media Australia (CN3381295) for engagement of an Instagram channel, (a) what Instagram channel was the subject of this contract, (b) what is the itemised breakdown of the services provided, (c) what was the period of the contract, and (d) what policy area did this relate to.
Mr Pyne: The Minister for Employment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(a) The Instagram channel which is the subject of the contract is @australiansatwork:
https://www.instagram.com/australiansatwork/.

(b) The service provided from Dentsu Mitchell Australia was the management of sponsored posts and video posts in the general newsfeed of Instagram at a cost of $45,454.55 + GST. The Instagram channel promotes and directs users to jobactive.gov.au.
(c) The period of the contract is 4 November 2016 – 28 February 2017.

(d) The material that was the subject of the contract was used for a range of portfolio programmes that assist individuals to become job ready and find employment. The Instagram channel was one of a number of instances in which this material has been utilised. The Instagram content has also been promoted on the jobactive website to support the launch of the Selfstart initiative, featured in myGov shopfronts and will appear in the department's mobile apps in future.
NBN
(Question No. 688)
Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications, in writing, on 20 March 2017
Is it a fact that
(a) NBN services provided through the NBN Sky Muster Satellite Service (SMSS) guarantee a maximum connection speed in the same way as metropolitan residential ADSL services, and

(b) the maximum connection speed provided through the SMSS is the maximum combined speed for all services connecting to the spot beam from the satellite; if so, do NBN rural and remote customers using the SMSS only receive a fraction of the theoretical maximum—that is, 1/n where
n = the number of active connections in the spot beam.
Mr Fletcher: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) NBN Sky Muster™ satellite services provide wholesale peak speeds of 25 Mbps/5Mbps.
(b) No, the maximum connection speed is that purchased by the end user in the Sky Muster footprint, this is 25/5.
NBN
(Question No. 689)
Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications, in writing, on 20 March 2017
(1) Are spot beams from the NBN Sky Muster Satellite Service (SMSS) across northern Australia classed as 'wide spot beams', and do they cover an area of approximately 330,000 square kilometres.

(2) Are users of NBN services provided through the SMSS unable to predict the level of congestion on wide spot beams and therefore, unable to reasonably predict the expected speed of a connection; if so, does this mean that users cannot deploy services that depend on minimum connection speeds such as VoIP or 'fat client'
Mr Fletcher: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) Sky Muster satellite coverage in northern Australia includes both 'narrow' and 'wide' spot beams. These beams cover, typically, territory with a radius of around 125km and 325km respectively. So the 'wide beam' covers an area of approximately 330,000 square kilometres.

(2) Individual retail service providers set congestion levels based on their own commercial drivers. Congestion levels are therefore not made public. Capacity on the Sky Muster service is managed via the application of the Fair Use policy and nbn's Sky Muster satellite product capacity restrictions (see WBA Product description at www.nbnco.com.au for further details) to ensure adequate speeds are achieved during the busy hour. Feedback from retail service providers indicates that VoIP services have been successfully deployed on Sky Muster satellite service.
NBN Co
(Question No. 692)
Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications, in writing, on 20 March 2017

Is it a fact that the NBN data caps are small, and the NBN has a 'fair usage' policy that enforces a restrictive data cap over a rolling four-week period, effectively reducing caps to a weekly allowance; if so, as a result of the small NBN data caps, are some businesses operating in remote areas forced to install multiple connections to ensure staff 'personal' use does not consume the bandwidth required for 'business' use.
Mr Fletcher: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
No, the NBN Sky Muster data caps are twice those planned by Labor.
The Government is working with NBN Co to increase data caps and launch business-grade connections.
Mobile Black Spots Program
(Question No. 696)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications, in writing, on 20 March 2017:

To ask the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications—In respect of mobile black spots (a) how many remain after Rounds 1 and 2 of the Mobile Black Spots Program, (b) what modelling has been done on the estimated cost to eliminate all identified mobile black spots, and will the Minister provide a copy of this modelling, and (c) what is the average cost of eliminating a single mobile black spot.
Mr Fletcher: The answer to the member's question is as follows:

(a) The database of reported mobile black spot locations has 10,802 eligible locations listed, as identified by the public, community organisations and local governments. Following Rounds 1 and 2 of the Mobile Black Spot Program, approximately 6,400 eligible locations of publicly identified black spot locations will remain on the database.
(b) Australia has a land mass of nearly eight million square kilometres. No modelling has been done on the estimated cost of eliminating all mobile black spots within Australia.

(c) The cost of deploying a mobile base station can vary significantly based on the type of base station (macrocell or small cell), location, topography, local government planning approval and landowner agreement where necessary, and/or the ability to access existing infrastructure, power and backhaul.

The average estimated capital cost of delivering a base station under Rounds 1 and 2 of the program can be calculated by dividing the total estimated capital investment ($597.6 million) by the total number of base stations (765). This equates to an average estimated capital cost of approximately $782,000 per base station.

Similarly, some 4,400 reported mobile black spot locations will be covered under Rounds 1 and 2 of the program. The estimated average cost per black spot can therefore be calculated by dividing the total estimated capital investment ($597.6 million) by the total number of black spots covered (4,400). This equates to an average estimated capital cost of approximately $135,800 per black spot. This cost could increase or decrease according to the specific nature of a particular black spot location.
Mobile Black Spot Program
(Question No. 697)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications, in writing, on 20 March 2017:
In respect of the Minister's departmental website stating that a competitive process to allocate Round 3 funding for the Mobile Black Spot Program is expected to commence in 2017:
(a) what progress has been made on this process?
(b) when will the details be announced?
(c) who will be eligible to apply for funding?
(d) what will be the conditions for funding?
(e) will a list of the sites be published, and then telecommunications companies be invited, to bid for a package?
Mr Fletcher: the answer to the Member's question is as follows:
(a) The Australian Government has allocated $60 million to the Mobile Black Spot Program to target specific priority locations.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) released a draft decision on 5 May 2017 to not declare wholesale domestic mobile roaming as a result of their mobile roaming inquiry.
Following this, consultations have now commenced with the mobile carriers and the

States on the implementation of the priority locations round of the Program. There will be an approach to market in 2017 to deliver on these commitments, subject to suitable applications being submitted by the mobile carriers.
(b) Information regarding the details of the Program will be included in the Program Guidelines, expected to be released later in 2017.
(c) It is currently anticipated that the mobile carriers and mobile infrastructure providers will be eligible to apply for funding.
(d) Information regarding the allocation of program funding will be included in the Program Guidelines.

(e) The list of priority locations is available on the Department of Communications and the Arts' website at www.communications.gov.au/mobile_coverage. More information regarding the allocation of program funding will be available in the Program Guidelines, expected to be released later in 2017.
Mobile Black Spot Program
(Question No. 699)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Communications, in writing, on 20 March 2017:
In respect of the Government announcing, as part of its commitment to Round 3 of the Mobile Black Spot Program, that a number of priority locations would receive funding:
(a) How many base stations were on the list compiled at the time of the announcement, and will the Minister present this list?
(b) What proportion of the $60 million will be committed if all of the base stations on the list are funded?
(c) How was this list compiled?
(d) Was there a consultation process for compiling this list?
(e) Did the Minister's department have a say in compiling this list or was it provided by the Minister's office?
(f) What was the process for seeking nominations for this list from Members of Parliament?
(g) Will the Minister publish the current list of priority locations to be funded?
(h) If communities are not on the list for Round 3, what is the process for them to apply for having mobile black spots addressed?
(i) How many mobile phone towers will be funded under Round 3?
Mr Fletcher: the answer to the Member's question is as follows:

(a) The targeted Mobile Black Spot Program locations were individually announced following the release of the Government's election policy paper The Coalition's Policy to Tackle Mobile Phone Black Spots on 24 May 2016. The list of election commitment locations is available on the Department of Communications and the Arts' website at www.communications.gov.au/mobile_coverage
(b) The Commonwealth committed $60 million to the election commitment priority locations. The final cost of the base stations will not be known until applications are received and assessed.
(c) The locations on the list are commitments made during the 2016 election campaign.
(d) See response to (c).

(e) As part of its routine practice of monitoring election commitments, the Department of Communications and the Arts compiled a list of the locations announced by the Government during the 2016 election campaign.
(f) See response to (c).
(g) See response to (a).
(h) People experiencing mobile coverage/reception issues should contact the mobile carriers to highlight their concerns.
(i) See response to (a).
Tasmanian Sewerage
(Question No. 708)
Mr Hart asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 21 March 2017:

In respect of Infrastructure Australia's January 2017 Infrastructure Priority List which identified 'Tasmanian sewerage infrastructure upgrades' as a proposed initiative and 'Tasmanian waste water treatment environmental compliance' as a problem (page 9), (a) is he aware that in 2015 the Margaret Street Pump Station in Launceston spilt raw effluent into the Tamar River more than 900 times, and (b) what support has been requested of the Australian Government from the Tasmanian Government, TasWater, or any local government authority within Tasmania in respect of (i) investigation, (ii) design, and (iii) funding, of any inadequacies of the sewerage and water infrastructure within Tasmania.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) The Australian Government is aware that elements of Tasmania's waste water treatment system do not meet current environmental standards.

(b) On 28 April 2016, the Joint Commonwealth and Tasmanian Economic Council (the Council) noted the challenges posed by Tasmania's ageing and dispersed water and sewerage infrastructure, and noted a funding model to address these challenges proposed by TasWater. The funding model proposed by TasWater included a $300 million Commonwealth contribution. The Council agreed to further discussions on how to address the challenges presented.
Tasmanian Sewerage
(Question No.709)
Mr Hart asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 21 March 2017:

In respect of Infrastructure Australia's January 2017 Infrastructure Priority List which identified 'Tasmanian sewerage infrastructure upgrades' as a proposed initiative and 'Tasmanian waste water treatment environmental compliance' as a problem (page 9), (a) has any material been supplied to the Australian Government on the likely cost of separation of sewerage and stormwater within the city of Launceston given it has a combined sewerage and stormwater system, without separation of sewerage and stormwater outflows, and (b) is there any material to suggest that the separation of sewerage and stormwater within the city of Launceston will have any effect on the incidence of discharge of raw sewerage in breach of environmental obligations.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(a) On 28 April 2016, the Joint Commonwealth and Tasmanian Economic Council (the Council) noted the challenges posed by Tasmania's ageing and dispersed water and sewerage infrastructure, and noted a funding model to address these challenges proposed by TasWater. The funding model proposed by TasWater included a $300 million Commonwealth contribution. The Council agreed to further discussions on how to address the challenges presented.
(b) The Australian Government is aware that separation of sewerage and stormwater in Launceston would be likely to reduce the frequency and volume of combined sewer overflows.
Tasmanian Sewerage
(Question No. 710)
Mr Hart asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 21 March 2017:

In respect of Infrastructure Australia's January 2017 Infrastructure Priority List which identified 'Tasmanian sewerage infrastructure upgrades' as a proposed initiative and 'Tasmanian waste water treatment environmental compliance' as a problem (page 9), (a) in light of the Australian Government either funding or facilitating a number of projects within the Tamar basin at Launceston, in particular flood protection, remediation and tourism developments, are the present sewerage treatment plants within the greater Launceston area (ie, Legana, Newnham, Riverside, Ti-Tree Bend, Hoblers Bridge, Norwood and Prospect Vale), constraining growth in economic activity in Northern Tasmania, and (b) has the Australian Government received any submissions on the likely increase in sewerage volume to the system, and the capacity for the Launceston sewerage system to cope with these anticipated volume increases.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) This Portfolio is not aware of any specific study showing that sewerage treatment plants in the Launceston area are constraining economic growth in Northern Tasmania.

(b) In September 2015, Infrastructure Australia received a submission from the Tasmanian Government which outlined the projected increase in sewage volumes in Launceston, and indicated that most of the existing Launceston sewerage treatment plants are reaching treatment capacity.
Road Safety
(Question No. 715)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 9 May 2017:

(1) Will the Government continue funding the keys2drive program beyond 30 June 2017; if not, (a) what modelling has been done to support withdrawal of the funding, and (b) has he appraised the rural/regional implications of withdrawing the funding.
(2) How many drivers aged 17 to 25 years were killed in road crashes in the calendar years (a) 2014, (b) 2015, (c) 2016, and (d) 2017 (to date).
(3) What proportion of drivers killed on Australia's roads are in the 17 to 25 age group, as compared to those in the over 25 age group.
(4) How many learner drivers participated in the keys2drive program in the calendar years (a) 2014, (b) 2015, (c) 2016, and (d) 2017 (to date), by (i) age, and (ii) state/territory.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) In the 2017-18 Budget, the Australian Government extended funding for the keys2drive programme, providing $16 million over four years.

Perth Freight Link
(Question No. 720)
Mr Josh Wilson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, in writing, on Tuesday 9 May 2017:

In respect of Main Roads Western Australia's 2 September 2016 options briefing paper for the then state Minister for Transport, Mr Dean Cambell Nalder MLA, regarding the contract award and construction approach for the Perth Freight Link (PFL), (a) was the (i) Minister, (ii) Minister's office, or (iii) the Minister's department, made aware, formally or informally, of the recommendation by Main Roads Western Australia to only proceed with the project prior to the state election in a form that minimised both the environmental damage and the sunk cost of the clearing and preliminary work; if so, was the Minister provided with a copy of the document, and (b) did the (i) Minister, (ii) Minister's office, or (iii) the Minister's department, discuss this advice, formally or informally, with the Western Australian Minister for Transport, his office, or his department; if so, did the (i) Minister, (ii) Minister's office, or (iii) the Minister's department, formally or informally provide advice to, comment on, or make a recommendation to, the Western Australian Government on how to proceed with the PFL; if so, what was it.
Mr Morrison: The Minister for Finance has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

The Australian Government worked closely with the Western Australian Government during the project development stage of the Perth Freight Link. Specific decisions regarding clearing works undertaken prior to the Western Australian state election are an operational matter managed solely by the Western Australian Government.

Budget
(Question No. 724)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister representing the Minister for Regional Development, in writing, on 11 May 2017:
(1) How many of the measures in the 2017-18 budget (a) required a Regional Australia Impact Statement (RAIS) to be completed, and (b) were exempt from completing a RAIS.
(2) Can the Minister provide a list that includes (a) each budget measure title, (b) the budget impact, and (c) whether a RAIS was completed.
(3) Can the Minister describe the process through which a RAIS is taken, including (a) how it is decided that one is required, and (b) what happens when it is drafted.
(4) What are the record keeping processes for the completed RAISs, and are these accessible to policy makers as a reference for development of future policy proposals.
(5) How many staff are responsible for the oversight of the RAISs, and what proportion of each staff member's time is dedicated to the RAIS process.
(6) Have there been any reviews of the RAIS process; if so, what were the outcomes.
Mr Chester: The Minister for Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
All agencies bringing forward measures in the 2017-18 Budget were required to assess the potential regional impact of those proposals.

(1) The number of measures for which a Regional Australia Impact Statement is prepared and the number of exemptions are not tracked. Regional Australia Impact Statements are an important part of the Australian Government's decision-making process and are prepared for all decisions with a significant impact on regional Australia. The guidelines for preparing a statement are available at www.infrastructure.gov.au.

(2) Details of initiatives that involve a significant investment in rural and regional Australia are outlined in the Government's Regional Ministerial Budget Statement Regional Australia– Driving Our Economy 2017-2018, released on 9 May 2017. Previous Regional Ministerial Budget Statements are available at www.infrastructure.gov.au.
(3) Refer to response to Question 1.
(4) Cabinet records are processed in accordance with the Archives Act 1983. Further information on processing of Cabinet records is available at www.naa.gov.au.
(5) Refer to response to Question 1.
(6) Regional Australia Impact Statements are part of the Cabinet submission process. Any reviews of the Cabinet submission process are confidential.
Disability Services
(Question No. 725)

(1) By Employment Service Area (ESA), how many people were assessed as meeting the Disability Employment Services—Employment Support Service (DES-ESS) funding levels 1 and 2 in (a) 2013-14, (b) 2014-15, (c) 2015-16 and (d) 2016-17 (to date). (2) By ESA, how many people moved from funding level 2 to level 1 in (a) 2013-14, (b) 2014-15, (c) 2015-16 and (d) 2016-17 (to date). (3) Can the Minister provide details of the plan to address the growing number of people using the DES-ESS in regional Australia.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

1. Table below shows the number of people by ESA who were assessed as meeting the DES-ESS funding levels 1 and 2 in (a) 2013-14, (b) 2014-15, (c) 2015-16 and (d) 2016-17 (to 22 May 2017) at commencement. The table does not include DES-ESS commencements that do not have a funding level.

3. Because Disability Employment Services is an uncapped program funded at the level of individual participants, an increase in the number of participants results in an increase in funding for service provision. This means that to the extent that there is an increase in the number of participants in DES-ESS in regional areas, more funding is paid to providers of DES-ESS servicing those participants in those regions.

The Australian Government announced reforms to the DES program in the 2017-18 Budget to take effect from mid-2018. Amongst those reforms is a move to a 'risk-adjusted' funding model. The new model assigns participants to payment levels according to their likelihood of gaining employment - paying more for those who are less likely to gain employment and less for those who are more likely. The model is based on actuarial analysis of several years of data. Local labour market conditions affect people's chances of employment, and this is taken into consideration in the new model when assigning participants to payment levels, so that in tougher labour markets, for a given profile of participants more people will be assigned into higher payment categories, and in easier labour markets, somewhat fewer will be assigned into higher payment categories. To the extent that regional labour markets are tougher, this means that for a given profile of participants, somewhat higher levels of funding will be available in those regions. Because labour market conditions can change, payments will periodically be recalibrated using the most recent available data to ensure they reflect changes, such as local downturns or upswings in the availability of employment.
Disability Services
(Question No. 726)
Ms McGowan asked the Minister for Social Services, in writing, on 11 May 2017:

In respect of Disability Employment Services (DES), (a) what modelling has been done by the Government (i) to take into account the increasingly higher level of non-funded services, such as housing needs, financial counselling, and other welfare referrals, being provided by regional providers as other community services decline, and (ii) on the impact of competition through the DES business reallocation resulting in only large national and/or international employment firms winning the tenders, (b) what measures has the Government put in place to work with smaller service providers to allow them more time to prepare and submit DES tenders and compete with larger organisations, (c) what action has the Minister taken to ensure there is a choice of service provider for clients, (d) what action is the Government taking to improve the transparency of the Star Rating System applied to employment service providers, (e) has a review been conducted into the effectiveness of the star rating system; if so, has performance improved, and (f) can the Minister supply data on how many service providers previously rated as either 1 or 2 stars, have closed in rural/regional Australia as compared to the metropolitan centres.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(a) (i) Fees for Disability Employment Services (DES) under the current contract were set for the term of the contract, prior to going to market. In tendering for DES business, and where successful, in entering into the contract, providers accepted the structure and level of the available fees for the term of the contract. Fees for Disability Employment Services are for support to people with disability to gain employment; they are not intended to meet the costs of a range of other services supported through other programs and services or the National Disability Insurance Scheme. In the 2017 budget, the Government has provided funding for indexation of payments under DES, at an estimated cost of over $300 million over 10 years.

(a) (ii) DES business reallocation is based on the relative performance of providers at the contract level – that is, by region by service (Disability Management Service or Employment Support Service). Neither size nor whether an organisation also operates overseas are factors considered in reallocation. The most recent DES business reallocation process, finalised in February 2017, resulted in 31 existing DES providers, receiving additional business in areas where the poor performing business of providers was removed. The 31 providers awarded the additional business comprise of a mix of small, medium and large, international and national organisations with high performing business in either the same Employment Services Area or similar.

(b) The current DES contracts are due to expire on 4 March 2018. Following feedback from the sector, the Government has decided to extend the current DES contracts from 5 March 2018 to 30 June 2018. This will help ensure providers have sufficient time to participate in the purchasing process alongside larger providers.

Further, following consultation regarding the reforms, specific elements of the current DES program model will be maintained to enable the continued viability of small providers in both metropolitan and regional areas. For example the program will maintain the current 110 Employment Services Areas (ESAs) in which DES providers will deliver services. While the possibility of moving to fewer, larger regions was canvassed, feedback told us that it was important to keep smaller regions to avoid requiring smaller providers to scale up to provide coverage of larger regions. The possibility of moving to a requirement for a single service covering both the Disability Management Service (DMS) and Employment Support Service (ESS) was canvassed. Feedback from the sector suggested that requiring particularly smaller providers that specialise in one of these services currently to expand their capability to cover both could put their viability and/or performance at risk, and also disadvantage them compared to larger providers that already cover both services.

(c) Through both the original tender processes and through reallocation the Government aims to ensure multiple providers are available and that choice remains available. Under the new arrangements commencing in 2018, this will be improved through periodically conducting rounds to add new DES providers and to enable existing providers to expand into new regions. This will avoid the current circumstance where there is no mechanism to add additional providers in a region during the period of the contract. Under the new DES model commencing in 2018, there will be no limit on the number of providers that can operate in a region, and referrals will not be managed to achieve agreed market shares for providers as they are under the current program. The removal of guaranteed market shares also means that providers will have to offer services that seek to attract and retain participants. Under the new arrangements, participants will also be able to connect with providers outside of the Employment Service Area (ESA) in which they reside, if they wish, offering greater choice.

(d) The Department of Social Services (DSS) provides detailed documents on how the DES Star Ratings are calculated. Online Presentations were delivered in 2013 for the current Star Ratings model, to explain how it operates and further additional presentations have also been conducted since 2013. A recording of the presentations is available for DES providers to access at any time. With any of the Star Ratings releases, DES providers can contact their contract manager for additional information regarding why they received specific Star Rating results that they do not understand. DES providers also have six-monthly formal performance reviews with their account manager where they also have opportunities to ask questions.

DES providers receive weekly performance reports, through a reporting portal, for the number of participants who have achieved an outcome (numerator) and those who are in scope for a performance measure (denominator). This information is available for all of their performance measures, across all of their contracts and outlets. This information allows them to track their performance on a more regular basis, as well as set their targets and monitor against them. In November 2016, a new performance report was released for DES providers that include the unit level (i.e. participant level) records of all of the participants included in their numerators and denominators for all performance measures. This enables DES providers to identify exactly which of their participants are included in the performance measures.

(e) DES Star Ratings are a measure of the relative performance of services, not the absolute performance. The performance of DES as a whole is subject to external factors, including changes in the labour market, levels of economic growth and activity and rates of employment and unemployment.
DES Star Ratings have been internationally recognised. For example, the OECD publication Sickness, Disability and Work: Breaking the Barriers 2010 stated:

span.span: Through its comprehensive Star Rating performance management system, Australia has gone furthest in monitoring the performance of service providers. A good rating is crucial for a provider to be included in the next round of tenders and thereby stay in the market. Employment outcomes for more difficult clients would raise the rating, for instance.

p.span: (f) Between March 2010 and March 2017, 594 contracts (provider's business in an employment services area (ESA)) performing at a 1 or 2-star rating were reallocated to an existing higher performing provider already in the ESA or a higher performing provider from a similar ESA. Of these 362 were in metro areas and 232 were in non-metro areas.

Only 19 contracts at a 1 or 2-star rating have ceased due to the provider handing back their business to DSS of their own accord. This comprises of 10 contracts in regional ESAs and nine in metropolitan ESAs.
Centrelink
(Question No. 728)
Mrs Elliot asked the Minister for Human Services, in writing, on 22 May 2017:

In respect of the impact of the implementation of the automated debt-recovery system on Centrelink offices in the electoral division of Richmond, (a) how many extra people are now seeking assistance, (b) how much longer are people spending waiting to be assisted, (c) how many Centrelink customers were sent letters informing them that they had been overpaid and would need to repay this debt, only to have this advice subsequently rescinded when queried, (d) have staff numbers been increased to cater for the higher volume of assistance sought, and (e) have staff sick days, resignations and retirements increased since the introduction of this system.
Mr Tudge: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

a) and b) The Department of Human Services (the Department) does not specifically capture information on individuals coming in to inquire about the Online Compliance Intervention. The Department tracks the overall number of people coming in and categorises them according to whether they are there for an appointment, a general inquiry or they are referred to self-service. The business levels in the Service Centres in the Electoral Division of Richmond have not varied and are within expectations.

c) 1,506 recipients have had a debt raised through Employment Income Matching while residing in the federal electorate of Richmond in the period from 1 July 2016 to 31 March 2017. Of those, 73 have subsequently had the debt amount reduced to zero. The debt can be reduced through a reassessment when an individual provides further information.

d) and e) Please refer to answer to a) and b). In addition, the Employment Income Matching Programme is a national programme administered by compliance officers with specific expertise and training in compliance and employment matching. Any individual with a query has been and is able to phone a dedicated number. This phone line is fully resourced. Consistent with the delivery of a national programme, compliance officers are located in different offices nationally, none of which are in the federal electoral division of Richmond. This means there has been no requirement to increase staff numbers in the electoral division of Richmond as a result of this programme.
Poly-fluoroalkyl Substances
(Question No. 731)
Mrs Elliot asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 22 May 2017:

In respect of the confirmation of Perfluorooctane Sulfonate and Perfluorooctanoic Acid contamination at the Gold Coast Airport, will he (a) commit to fully restoring all contaminated soils and ground waters around the Gold Coast Airport, (b) ensure that the process in part (a) is open and accountable, and (c) take all possible steps to prevent such contamination of local wetlands and waterways.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

A preliminary site investigation for per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) was conducted at Gold Coast Airport by an independent environmental consultant, GHD Pty Ltd, in July 2016. The study was commissioned by Airservices Australia (Airservices) who publicly released the final report in November 2016. The results showed low levels of PFAS, below guidelines for the protection of human health, at the airport boundary. No PFAS was detected in surface water samples in the Cobaki Broadwater.

Airservices subsequently commissioned a further independent seafood sampling program to better understand potential PFAS exposure pathways on human consumption of fish caught in the Cobaki Broadwater. The biota sampling was conducted in accordance with sampling protocols established by the NSW Department of Primary Industries. Airservices released the results of the seafood sampling in March 2017 which showed PFAS concentrations below the limit of detection in surface water, sediment and biota samples for the Cobaki Broadwater. The report concluded the risk to humans from consumption of fish, crustaceans and molluscs collected from Cobaki Broadwater is negligible.

These results confirm there is no risk of PFAS migrating off Gold Coast Airport. Commensurate with the risk, it would be unreasonable to require all potentially contaminated soils and ground waters around Gold Coast Airport to be fully restored.

Gold Coast Airport Pty Ltd and Airservices conduct regular groundwater and surface water monitoring of PFAS to monitor any potential movements of PFAS across the Airport. Airservices has also commissioned a further sampling program on the north-eastern side of the Airport in Queensland to test local spear bores off-airport and to test for PFAS along the Coolangatta Creek. Sampling will commence shortly once the scope of the investigation has been approved by the relevant Queensland authorities.

It is worth noting a report by the United Nations Industrial Development Organization in 2009 points out only 3% of globally manufactured perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS), a major PFAS chemical, by the US company 3M Lightwater was used in making firefighting foam. Almost half (48%) of total PFOS production was used in surface treatment applications (e.g. soil, oil and water resistance on apparel and leather, fabric/upholstery and carpets); 33% in paper protection (food and non food applications); and 15% in performance chemicals (e.g. mist suppressants for metal plating, floor polishes, photographic film, denture cleaners, shampoos, carpet spot cleaners). This report emphasises the fact that firefighting foam constitutes only a small fraction of the total source of PFAS in the environment, i.e. other diffuse sources of PFAS contribute more than 90% of PFAS in the environment. Off-airport sources of PFAS may include sewage treatment plants, landfills, domestic fire extinguishers, mining operations, fuel refineries and storage facilities, urban and country fire-fighting facilities and fire suppression systems in high cost infrastructure, such as tunnels and rail maintenance facilities.

While low levels of PFAS are widespread in the environment, there is currently no consistent evidence that these chemicals are harmful to human health. However, as a precaution, the Australian Government recommends exposure be reduced wherever possible, while research into potential PFAS health effects continues.
Pension
(Question No. 732)
Mrs Elliot asked the Minister for Social Services, in writing, on 22 May 2017:

In respect of the impact on age pensioners in the electoral division of Richmond of the 1 January 2017 changes to the pension assets test, (a) what total number of age pensioners have been affected, (b) how many age pensions have (i) been reduced, (ii) been increased, and (iii) remained unchanged, and (c) how many age pensioners have entirely lost their age pension or part pension.
Mr Porter: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) On 1 January 2017, 4,539 age pensioners in the electoral division of Richmond were affected by the changes to the assets test.
Drones
(Question No. 739)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 29 May 2017:

In respect of reported incidences involving drones between 26 May 2015 and 26 May 2017, how many accidents or near-accidents, breaches of privacy or other regulations have been reported (a) over Australian airspace, and (b) over South Australian airspace, (c) over the airspace of our capital cities including metropolitan (i) Adelaide, (ii) Perth, (iii) Darwin, (iv) Brisbane, (v) Sydney, (vi) Canberra, (vii) Hobart, and (viii) Melbourne, and (d) within a (i) 20, (ii) 15, (iii) 10, and (iv) 5, kilometre radius of the Adelaide Airport.
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) collects information on the number of aviation safety occurrences reported in accordance with the mandatory occurrence reporting requirements of the Transport Investigation Act 2003 (TSI Act) and associated aviation safety regulations. The information on occurrences collected by the ATSB is categorised into three types:

Accidents: An occurrence involving an aircraft where: a person dies or suffers serious injury; the aircraft (which includes a drone) is destroyed or seriously damaged; or any property is destroyed or seriously damaged.
Serious Incidents: An incident involving circumstances indicating that an accident nearly occurred.

Incidents: An occurrence, other than an accident, associated with the operation of an aircraft which affects or could affect the safety of operation and also meets the definition of a 'Transport Safety Matter' in the TSI Act.
Available information on the number of aviation safety related occurrences as requested, is in the table below.

The ATSB has advised that it is currently reviewing the Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems occurrence data for the first half of 2017 and expects to publish updated figures and analysis in August 2017.
Information on incidents that are not aviation safety related, for example, privacy, are a matter for the relevant authority in each state and territory.

span.span: Number of drone-related aviation safety occurrences reported to the ATSB –

p.span: a. In Australian Airspace
b. In South Australian Airspace
c. In Capital City Airspace 1
i. Adelaide
ii. Perth
iii. Darwin
iv. Brisbane
v. Sydney
vi. Canberra
vii. Hobart
viii. Melbourne
d. Within radius of Adelaide Airport
i. 20km
ii. 15km
iii. 10km
iv. 5km
Source: ATSB National Occurrence Database - detailed data on occurrences involving remotely piloted aircraft for the period 26/5/15 to 26/5/17 (http://data.atsb.gov.au/DetailedData)

1 For the purposes of this response, 'Capital City Airspace' has been defined as Class C and D airspace, which is the controlled airspace and control zones around major airports (Class C) and the controlled airspace and control zones around controlled metropolitan and regional airports (Class D).

2 All 'accidents' reported to the ATSB involved damage to the drone (which is defined as an 'aircraft' for the purposes of this reporting) or other property only. No accidents involved injuries to persons or damage to other aircraft.
Adelaide Airport
(Question No. 740)
Mr Georganas asked the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, in writing, on 29 May 2017:

(1) What are the terms of any formal agreements that are or have been in place involving his department, Airservices Australia, and/or any Government agency with helicopter operators and Adelaide Airport Limited, in respect of preferred routes for (a) approach, (b) take-off, and (c) landing, at Adelaide Airport.

(2) What measures are in place with his department, Airservices Australia, and/or any Government agency with helicopter operators and Adelaide Airport Limited, to safeguard the wellbeing of residents who live around Adelaide Airport, including protecting them from helicopter noise?
Mr Chester: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) The only formal agreement in place with respect to helicopter operators at Adelaide Airport is a Letter of Agreement 844 (LoA 844) between Airservices Australia and the company that operates emergency medical, rescue and police flights on behalf of the SA Government.
Under the LoA 844, the parties agree to:
take all reasonable measures to minimise noise disturbance to members of the community;
be aware of potential noise outcomes relating to their operations as a result of the LoA 844;
work to identify, investigate and where possible implement noise improvement measures; and
that reviews of the LoA 844 will take into consideration noise complaints relating to the operations undertaken as part of the LoA 844.
(2) There are a range of measures in place to safeguard the wellbeing of residents who live around Adelaide Airport, including protecting them from helicopter noise.

The Adelaide Airport Consultative Committee (AACC) provides a forum for community members through appointed representatives to have matters considered and ideas explored about ways in which aircraft noise issues can be more effectively managed to reduce the impact on surrounding communities.

Procedures for helicopter operations and other aircraft operating at Adelaide are considered by the Adelaide Airport Technical Working Group (AATWG), a subgroup of the AACC. The AATWG, comprising Airservices, Adelaide Airport and the Department of Infrastructure and Regional Development, was established in 2015 to ensure that aircraft operations are conducted in accordance with procedures relevant to a particular aircraft type. The AATWG also investigates specific matters raised at the AACC by members of the Committee including in relation to the impacts of aviation noise on the community.

Approach, landing and take-off procedures for helicopters are set out in the En Route Supplement (ERSA) which forms part of the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP). The AIP is a package of documentation provided to pilots operating into, within, and out of Australia which sets out requirements to be observed at airports within Australia. The LoA 844 also sets out approach, landing and take-off procedures for helicopters. Both of these instruments have provisions to minimise helicopter noise wherever possible.
The ERSA provides that, subject to traffic, weather and priority considerations, helicopters shall adhere to the following departure and arrival routes:
North-west – via University playing fields and River Torrens outlet
South-west – via Sea Rescue Squadron or Sewerage Treatment Works
North – over Kooyonga Golf Course
East – via Richmond Road and Keswick railway bridge
South – via Glenelg Golf Course

The ERSA also states that, during night time hours, air traffic control and pilots will endeavour to confine as much noise as possible within the boundary of the aerodrome by ensuring helicopters depart and arrive overhead the Control Tower.

As set out in the LoA 844, local air traffic control works with operators to review arrival and departure procedures and noise issues on a regular basis. Wherever possible, given the proximity of the three major hospitals to populous residential areas, Adelaide parklands, railway lines or industrial areas are utilised to minimise noise. However, due to the random nature of the emergency rescue operations, some transit over populated areas is unavoidable.

Current issues under discussion by Airservices include those associated with the impending move to the new Royal Adelaide Hospital site. Options for minimising potential noise impacts associated with operations to and from the airport and the hospital are being considered, and consultation has taken place with the AACC.

Only emergency helicopters are permitted to operate during the curfew period at Adelaide Airport in accordance with the Adelaide Airport Curfew Act 2000 to protect the surrounding community from the adverse effects of aircraft noise.
There are currently approximately 3,600 helicopter movements per annum, or around 10 per day, at Adelaide Airport.
Holden
(Question No. 743)

Mr Champion
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, in writing, on 01 June 2017:

On how many occasions since December 2013 have representatives of the Minister's department met with representatives of the workforce from the Holden factory in South Australia, and on each of these occasions, (a) how many (i) departmental representatives, and (ii) Holden workforce representatives, were present, and (b) what was the (i) purpose, and (ii) outcome, of the meeting, and if exact numbers cannot be provided, can the Minister provide estimates.
Mr Pyne: The Minister for Employment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question

Since December 2013, the Department of Employment has regularly engaged with Holden's South Australian (SA) workforce to assist their retrenched workers to transition to new employment. This engagement has involved departmental officers from the National Office, State Office, and the Employment Facilitator.

Departmental officers have attended meetings of the National Governance Committee and Data Reference Group which have also included representatives from Holden. In addition, departmental officers have provided labour market information sessions to Holden workers.

The National Governance Committee (NGC) facilitates a 'whole of government' approach to programmes and services offered to retrenched automotive workers. The NGC was formed in September 2014, to share knowledge among parties, collaborate over mutual priorities and avoid duplication of efforts. The NGC has met on eleven occasions. The NGC is comprised of the Australian Government Departments of Industry, Employment and Education and Training, the Governments of South Australia and Victoria, and General Motors Holden and Toyota Motor Corporation Australia (OEMs). These meetings were attended by one or two departmental staff and between one to two Holden representatives.

Through the NGC departmental staff provided Holden representatives with employment services information and advice to assist their workforce to transition to new careers. This has included the provision of labour market projections, to identify growth industries with future job opportunities and the benefits of upskilling or recognition of prior learning.

Information about jobactive and the support available to retrenched Holden automotive workers through the Department's Automotive Industry Structural Adjustment Programme (AISAP) has also been provided. The NGC has also discussed planning for a number of high profile Job Fairs targeting automotive workers across South Australia and Victoria, including promoting the skills sets of automotive workers to prospective employers.

In addition to the NGC meetings have also occurred between departmental staff and Holden to discuss supporting Holden's workforce in the lead up to closure. These meetings were attended by between one and three departmental staff and one Holden representative.

The Department of Employment chaired a sub-committee of the NGC; the Data Reference Group (DRG), which was formed in February 2017 to discuss matters of data collection, has met on four occasions. These meetings were attended by between two to three departmental staff and between one and two Holden representatives. The DRG gained agreement among members to align data collection.

Between 1 December 2013 and 23 June 2017, the department provided 16 labour market information sessions for Holden workers on three separate visits to the Holden Transition Centre in Northern Adelaide. Approximately 1020 Holden workers attended these information sessions. On average, four departmental representatives presented at these sessions.

The presentations disseminate labour market information and data collected from the Survey of Employers' Recruitment Experiences. The sessions with Holden workers were to assist them to transition to other employment as quickly as possible following the company's closure. The sessions provided a realistic view of the local labour market, encouraged workers to undertake further training, and provided advice on employer expectations.

The Department has also had numerous ad-hoc meetings with Holden's South Australian workforce since December 2013; these meetings involved one to two departmental state office staff. These meeting were attended by anywhere from one to multiple Holden staff, depending on the meeting's purpose.

The meetings have included the delivery of information sessions about the assistance available to retrenched Holden workers from the jobactive Automotive Industry Structural Adjustment Programme (AISAP). Departmental officers also assisted in organising mini job fairs on site, as well as arranging Australian government employment service providers to meet retrenched workers.. The department has been present at the Holden transition centre on a monthly basis to advise affected workers on the support of the AISAP.

Along with the Department of Human Services and other contracted support onsite, such as career coaches or job placement, the department was present to deliver information to workers who left in 2015. These talks occurred throughout 2015 and were available at varying times to accommodate different shifts; including some sessions in the evening so that partners and family members could attend. Departmental officers also participated in various special events hosted at the transition centre. These special events included sessions targeted to female Holden employees.

From 7 November 2016, the department engaged an Employment Facilitator for the Adelaide region. The Facilitator provides on the ground support for workers affected by firm closures. The Facilitator has been in contact with the Holden workforce for a number of activities; these have included spending time at Holden's Elizabeth transition centre, including being based onsite on a regular basis. This has also involved meetings with Holden's Transition Manager on a monthly basis to plan for assistance in the coming month. The Facilitator also has ongoing meetings with individual employees or former employees about their linkages with employment service providers.
Holden
(Question No. 744)
Mr Champion asked the Minister for Industry, Innovation and Science, in writing, on 01 June 2017:

On how many occasions since December 2013 have representatives of the Minister's department met with representatives of the workforce from the Holden factory in South Australia, and on each of these occasions, (a) how many (i) departmental representatives, and (ii) Holden workforce representatives, were present, and (b) what was the (i) purpose, and (ii) outcome, of the meeting, and if exact numbers cannot be provided, can the Minister provide estimates.
Mr Hunt: The Minister for Industry, Innovation and Science has provided the following response to the honourable member's question:

Representatives of the Department of Industry, Innovation and Science have not met with representatives of the workforce of the Holden factory since December 2013. The Department meets regularly with representatives of Holden management.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Human Services: Holden workers (Question No. 745)

Unemployment
(Question No. 754)

Ms Madeleine King
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, in writing, on 19 June 2017:
In each quarter since July 2016 (to date), what was the unemployment rate in the (a) electoral division of Brand, (b) City of Kwinana, and (c) City of Rockingham, in the 15 to 24 age group.
Mr Pyne: The Minister for Employment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Youth (persons aged 15 to 24 years) unemployment rates at the electorate and Local Government Area (LGA) level are only available from the 2011 ABS Census of Population and Housing.

At the time of the 2011 Census, the youth unemployment rate was 12.5 per cent in the electorate of Brand, 14.0 per cent in the LGA of Kwinana and 12.0 per cent in the LGA of Rockingham. Data from the 2016 Census are scheduled to be released in October 2017.
Closing the Gap
(Question No. 761)
Ms Sharkie asked the Minister representing the Minister for Indigenous Affairs in writing, on 22 June 2017:

(1) What is the process for refreshing the Closing the Gap framework, including how the Australian Government will be engaging with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations, and state and territory governments.(2) How will the Redfern Statement be considered and feed into the refresh process.(3) What are the timeframes for the refresh process.
Mr Turnbull: has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

The refresh of the Closing the Gap agenda will focus on a strength-based approach that supports Indigenous advancement, working in partnership with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. This includes working with leaders who raise important issues for improving Indigenous outcomes, such as the Redfern Statement.

In its meeting, in June 2017, the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) agreed to develop a refreshed agenda and targets over the remainder of 2017. COAG also agreed to develop implementation principles and provide advice to COAG's second meeting in 2017 on an approach for the next phase of Closing the Gap.
